pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.3.9: I have here translated _kāya_ as breath in accordance with the usage in the Ānāpānasati Sutta [](mn118:24.6) where the breath is specifically said to be a body among bodies. This is also the explanation at [Sp.1.165](): _Sakalassa assāsakāyassa ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ viditaṃ karonto pākaṭaṃ karonto “assasissāmī”ti sikkhati_, “He trains, ‘I will breath in’, producing knowledge of and familiarity with the beginning, the middle, and the end of the whole body of the breath.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:2.49: _Satthahāraka_. I here follow Richard Gombrich’s interpretation of this word. See “The Mass Suicide of Monks in Discourse and Vinaya Literature”, by Analayo, Journal of the Oxford Centre for Buddhist Studies, 7: 11-55, 2014.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:5.4.2: “For a certain event” is not found in the Pali, but has been added to make the Pali idiom clearer.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:5.13.1: The Pali seem to say that he simply fell off the cliff, _papatanto_, but the context seems to require something more deliberate. Perhaps it is just an idiom.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:5.18.22: It is not an offense entailing expulsion because he was aiming to kill the child, not the mother.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:5.23.1: The text doesn’t say what the legal procedure, the _saṅghakamma_, was about, but it seems implied that it was against that monk. This is also the position of the subcommentary at [](Sp-ṭ̣.2.187): _Kammādhippāyāti: tajjanīyādikammakaraṇādhippāyā_, “Aiming at a legal procedure: aiming at doing a legal procedure of censure, etc.” The monks from the group of seventeen were in regular conflict with the monks from the group of six.
